did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.physdesc: Reports, course materials, printed materials, publications, research materials, and correspondence.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Collection consists of Kenneth M. Reardon's professional papers, including correspondence, teaching materials, and community plans and studies.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Kenneth M. Reardon is a professor of city planning specializing in neighborhood and community planning. He received his B.A. in Sociology from the University of Massachusetts Amherst in 1976, a Master of Urban Planning from Hunter College of the City University of New York in 1982, and a Ph.D. in City and Regional Planning from Cornell University in 1990. From 1990 to 1999, Reardon served on the planning faculty at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, where his work in establishing the East St. Louis Action Research Project earned him the AICP President's Award and the Dale Prize for Excellence in City Planning. He then taught and was chair of the Department of City and Regional Planning at Cornell University from 1999-2008, pursuing research, teaching, and outreach in the areas of neighborhood planning, community development, and community/university development partnerships. During his time in Ithaca, he coordinated the department's New Orleans Planning Initiative, which produced a recovery plan for the Ninth Ward. From 2008 to 2015, he served as director of the graduate program for the Department of City and Regional Planning at the University of Memphis, where he coordinated two resident-led economic and community development planning efforts in South Memphis. Since 2015, Reardon has been professor and director of the master's program in Urban Planning and Community Development at the University of Massachusetts Boston.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of Kenneth M. Reardon's professional papers, including correspondence, teaching materials, and community plans and studies.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Kenneth M. Reardon papers, #8528. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

did.unittitle: University- Community Partnership Power Disparities by Janni Sorensen, Ph.D.

scopecontent.p: A dissertation on power disparities in the case of the longstanding university-community partnership between the university's East St. Louis Action Research Project and neighborhood based groups in East St. Louis; focuses on participatory planning process in terms of who participates, how participation takes place, and the outcomes of the planning processes.

scopecontent.p: This plan was created to provide a framework for the Edgement Citizens for Crime Prevention and Community Development to develop future projects, and includes a historic and present (1995) context of the Edgemont neighborhood; authored by two of Professor Reardon's master's students (Ricardo A. Alarcón and Damon Y. Smith) in collaboration with residents of Edgemont and the East St. Louis Action Revitalization Project Prepared for and in cooperation with the Edgemont Citizens for Crime Prevention & Community Development. University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Department of Urban and Regional Planning.

did.unittitle: Emerson Park. Proposal and Preliminary Findings for Neighborhood Improvement Plan (NIP)

scopecontent.p: The preliminary findings and outline on the Emerson Park neighborhood which was soon transformed into a complete Neighborhood Improvement Plan (NIP) five months later; also included is a proposal for an Emerson Park Action Research Project by the university's Neighborhood Planning Workshop presented to the Emerson Park Neighborhood Coalition, the beginnings of the Emerson Park Neighborhood Improvement Plan; also contains a contact list for Emerson Park stakeholders and Emerson Park Institutional Interview Mailing List.

Catalogues deteriorating neighborhood conditions and presents directives for addressing such conditions. Census Data for Emerson Park/ Selected Areas from 1960's - 1990. The Emerson Park Plans include Neighborhood Improvement Plan for Emerson Park (1991), Community Safety Plan for Emerson Park (1992) and Emerson Community Development Block Grant Program (1992-1997). Population and Housing in Emerson Park. Emerson Park Research Project.

This plan was created as a guide to coordinate the efforts of local residents, law enforcement officials and public officials in improving neighborhood safety. An executive summary of the plan in addition to correspondence with the U.S. Department of Justice Drug Enforcement Administration regarding the East St. Louis Crime Prevention Project are included.

did.unittitle: Emerson Park Community Development Block Grant Program Proposal

scopecontent.p: Funding proposal for the Neighborhood Technical Assistance Center as operated by the university Board of Trustees; draft budget amendment for Fiscal Year 1998/1999 for the Neighborhood Technical Assistance Center.

Includes examples of materials that were housed in the NTAC including East St. Louis Action Research Project (ESLARP) annual reports and overviews and a Request for Assistance form which includes a summary of NTAC's mission and program activities

scopecontent.p: Correspondence. "Regional Empowerment Zone. Building the Bridge". Community Profiles for Greater East St. Louis Enterprise Communities. Population and Housing Data (1960 - 1997) Booklets. Application materials for Empowerment Zone or Enterprise Community designation for the Greater St. Louis region; materials include a letter from Illinois Governor Jim Edgar to the Secretary of HUD, community profiles and projects for Greater St. Louis, which specifically includes Emerson Park in the Neighborhood/Community Development Implementation Projects section, and population and housing profiles for Greater East St. Louis.

Proposal for community schools as places to improve health care for children and families, to reduce crime especially among young people, and to increase recreational programs for children in four targeted areas in East St. Louis; partial plan only.

This comprehensive community development initiative focuses on employment, housing, public safety, municipal, and social services needs of the Lansdowne Neighborhood laying-out a five-year development strategy; first year programming on affordable housing, open space planning, and employment initiatives; Lansdowne Neighborhood Research Project summary of findings also included. The Lansdowne Community Development Block Grant Proposal 1992 - 1996. A Five Year Plan for the Lansdowne Awareness Community Committee. Neighborhood Improvement Plan for Lansdowne.
National Register of Historic Places Nomination Packet for places in the Olivette Park neighborhood and contributions to a neighborhood historic district

Neighborhood Summit packet for an attendee, including an agenda, handouts on the goals for the summit, an evaluation form for feedback on the summit, a SWOT analysis from the Olivette Park Action Revitalization Plan, Olivette Park Neighborhood Association and other neighborhood stakeholder contact information

The museum is named after and filled with the art collections of Katherine Dunham, an East St. Louis institutional leader. The museum is located in within the Pennsylvania awards Avenue Historic District in a building on the Illinois Historic Registry and was directly tied into the Cultural Redevelopment District Plan. This museum houses Ms. Dunham's collection of African, West African, and South American art, inclusive of Ms. Dunham's costumes, photography, programs, letters, awards, and mementos from her career as a dancer, choreographer, teacher, and dance company owner.

Vol. 3: Faculty and Student Projects, comprised of contributions from UIUC School of Architecture, covers a variety of planning topics specific to east St. Louis, including GIS mapping, fundraising, computer based planning assessment tools, industrial development, land use strategies, housing, and transportation University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Department of Urban and Regional Planning.

did.unittitle: East St. Louis Action Research Project (ESLARP) Report
ESLARP: Annual Reports and Project Summaries

scopecontent.p: Articles about or mentioning ESLARP in The New Public Innovator; a piece written by Ed Wisneski from Southern Methodist University; "Participatory Action Research in East St. Louis" written by a UIUC graduate student Kirk Goodrich and Ph.D. student Lucia Resende, Spring 1993. Also included are an informational pamphlet about ESLARP; a flyer advertising an event "Community Revitalization along the Mississippi," sponsored by ESLARP and featuring Dr. Reardon as a speaker; flyer for the Downtown Community Forum, "City Back From The Edge: Creating University/Community Partnerships"; flyers publicizing ESLARP and Egrets, an online geographic information guide for East St. Louis.

"Trustees Approve More than $2 Billion Operating Budget; Alumni News Volume 20. College of Fine and Applied Arts. University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Department of Urban and Regional Planning; Flyers for "Phil Gramm's War on CRA. Analysis & Commentary); COPC (Community Outreach Partnership Centers) Central. "Colleges and Universities work well with CDBG"; "University Accepts Challenge to Revive a City"; "A Sustainable Community/ University Partnership" by Kenneth M. Reardon; State of the States "One Poor City's 'Awesome; Project"; Correspondence. ESLARP Booklets.

State of the States "One Poor City's 'Awesome; Project"; Washington Post Article "University-Community Breakthrough in East St. Louis. University of Illinois makes a 'best practice' of East St. Louis, helping students and residents".

Articles include Inside Illinois - "Martin"; The Champaign-Urbana news-Gazette - "City to Start Group in Garden Hills"; "Students' work gives E. St. Louis children place to play"; Connections, East St. Louis Action Research Project - "Riches Amidst the Rubble of East St. Louis"; East St. Louis Farmers' Market brochure.

scopecontent.p: Background information about East St. Louis economy, government, and general history of the city.
Demographic information about race, labor, population change, unemployment, income, household and more.

did.unittitle: Articles Related to ESL About Planning and Partcipation

scopecontent.p: "Patterns of Community Development by Richard Franklin; "The Context for Planning in East St. Louis"

did.unittitle: Bond for Deed Survey Instruments and Interview Notes

scopecontent.p: Survey instruments for interviewing Winstanley Neighborhood residents, institutional stakeholders, and other stakeholders in regards to how bond for deed affects properties and interviewees; in addition to bond for deed, there is a housing survey, interview agendas, guidelines, and notes. Interviews and surveys were conducted, and materials were created for and/or by the Community Planning Workshop.

did.unittitle: Bond for Deed Winstanley/Industry Park Neighborhood Outreach Materials

scopecontent.p: Public service, press release, fact sheets, and other outreach materials to Winstanley/Industry Park Neighborhood Organization (WIPNO) and all East St. Louis residents interested in or involved in bond for deed contracts to engage the community in a Housing Improvement Campaign, a community education and outreach campaign. Also included in this folder are Professor Reardon's personal notes on the impacts of bond-for-deed in East St. Louis

did.unittitle: Bond for Deed Government and Legislative Advocacy

scopecontent.p: Documents include existing Illinois state ordinance in regards to regulation of sales of dwelling structure by installment sales contracts and the history of the ordinance, related laws; a proposal for contract for deed reform from Illinois state Senator Rosson; and a memo from the Illinois Governor Jim Edgar's office regarding the legislation put forth by state Representative Wyvetter Younge (D-East St. Louis) specifically to require the seller of real estate property by installment contract to provide proper notices, tax bills concerning the property being transferred to the purchaser, and that the contract be recorded, lest the contract seller assume liability for any damages resulting in failure to record the contract. The document from the Governor's office also includes a brief bill analysis. Additional law review resources.

did.unittitle: "Developers' Guide to Affordable Housing in East St. Louis"

scopecontent.p: Chapters included are: Direct Action, Selecting and Researching Winnable Issues, Understanding Power, Organizing Public Actions, Stop the Press: Working the media, Fundraising and Basics of Organizational Finance, Recruitment and Outreach, Conducting Effective Meetings,

ESL CAN Community Organizing, Training Seminar, Materials and Notes.
Community Outreach Partnership Centers (COPC) Program 2-yr Proposal

scopecontent.p: Proposal to expand on the ESLARP successes and community outreach; specifically to expand planning and program implementation capacity, continue the neighborhood college, establish a neighborhood technical assistance center, and a research project on the best strategies for dealing with depopulating small cities like East St. Louis.

did.unittitle: COPC Program Revisions and Updates I and II

scopecontent.p: A funding proposal expanding the services of the Neighborhood Technical Assistance Center and citizen organization, economic and housing development.

did.unittitle: Alta Sita Neighborhood Summit and Community Participation Materials

scopecontent.p: Planning materials, invitations and contact list, neighborhood SWOT analysis based on interviews with neighborhood residents, development plan outlines for feedback, and other preparatory materials/notes.

did.unittitle: Winstanley Industry Park Neighborhood Improvement Plan (WIPNIP)

scopecontent.p: Describes current neighborhood conditions and views of local residents; lays out a 5-year strategic plan to stabilize the area, addressing topics such as health and safety interventions, infrastructure improvements, housing, urban design, employment and economic development, crime reduction,, and the recommended implementation of new city-wide and regional policies.

did.unittitle: Winstanley Industry Park Neighborhood Organization (WIPNO) proposals and community participation materials

Looks at the prevalence and the advantages/disadvantage of the use of installment land contracts as an instrument used in lieu of traditional mortgages to buy homes in East St. Louis and makes recommendations for future regulation of the installment land contract market

scopecontent.p: Outlines a strategy to re-establish the center as a vital arts organization in east St. Louis by improving its organizational capacity and preserving its valuable cultural resources; this folder also includes two letters commemorating Katherine Dunhum during black history month in February 1998 as part of a fundraising campaign for the Center, and a program for the DunhamFest celebration event.
Includes development budget, proposals, vendors agreement, designs and phases.

did.unittitle: Community Meeting and Stakeholder Participatory Materials

scopecontent.p: Includes steering Committee agendas, notes, attendance sheets and contact information for community stakeholders; community organizing and neighborhood-wide meeting agendas, planning notes, schedules; meeting invitations and flyers; pulpit and bulletin announcements; May 2010 charette agenda and sign-in; letters and petitions for organizational, faith-based, and individual support for SoMeRAP; a work plan to gather support for SoMeRAP; community service award recognition by the Tennessee Medical Association for SoMeRAP and off-shoot community projects
Includes planning agendas and notes pre-summit; flyers, pulpit and bulletin announcements, sign-in sheet, agenda, meeting facilitator note guidelines, meeting evaluation form

did.unittitle: Neighborhood Community Stakeholder Profile: St. Andrew A.M.E. Church

scopecontent.p: Includes St. Andrew's history, PowerPoint of their enterprise business plan, and community resources St. Andrew A.M.E. Church, a co-founder in the South Memphis Renaissance Collaborative and partner in the SoMeRAP process is a neighborhood anchor institution in South Memphis.

Includes student work on existing physical conditions including land use, architectural style, building conditions, and other assessments, in addition to evaluations of proposed alternatives aimed at enhancing the physical conditions of the neighborhood

Includes neighborhood tour itinerary, fieldwork guide, interview guidelines, resident interview inventory sheet, maps of resident interview service areas, student sign-up sheets and schedules for resident interviews, including a community volunteer sign-in record

Includes resident interview inventories by student interviewers, resident opinion surveys drafts and final versions, Survey Monkey analysis of resident opinions; additional summary of some responses on key questions

Includes community stakeholder interview guide, two interview transcriptions from interviews with St. Andrew AME Church religious leaders, institutional interview contact list, interview questions for religious leaders, community stakeholders

Includes "Part I: Introducing the Plan and the Community", public safety initiatives, "South Memphis Revitalization Action Project Transportation", physical development, public health, and South Parkway East plan. Signature project summaries and group work documents with immediate/short, intermediate, and long-term initiatives and goals; these signature projects are featured in the final SoMeRAP

did.unittitle: Parkway Plaza: South Memphis Market Study and Feasibility Analysis SPECIAL PROJECTS STUDIO

scopecontent.p: Includes executive summary and draft of "Parkway Plaza: South Memphis Market Study & Feasibility Analysis. Special Project Studio's market analysis study on proposed retail space based on community surveys, census tract analysis, and pro forma analysis of construction and operating costs identifying a gap between household spending power in the Parkway Plaza trade area and estimated sales of existing retailers, positive return projections and recommendations;

did.unittitle: Community Meeting and Stakeholder Participation Materials

scopecontent.p: Includes Steering Committee, Advisory Board, and general meeting agendas and notes; 2011 preliminary work plan for farmers market; letters (drafts and final versions) to neighbors and local pastors around the South Memphis area with an invitation to join the South Memphis Farmers Market for orientation meetings, being involved in the market's opening and a press conference, and other related outreach efforts to ensure the market is a success; brochure on 2011 season; 2011 season social activities calendar
Includes Kenneth M. Reardon's hand-written field work and planning notes from meetings on the development of the South Memphis Farmer's Market, a major signature project in the SoMeRAP

Includes proposed site plan for South Memphis Farmers Market, an application (by The Works, Inc., a community stakeholder) for the market to be on a permanent site, includes a development budget. Additional note: Permanent site development was approved and the market opened in the summer of 2010

Includes materials in packet to invite farmers to participate in the market: fact sheet on the South Memphis Farmers Market; handout on the top-10 reasons on why vendors should join the market; vendor application and agreement, inclusive of proposed vendor sale items; and market season rules and regulations (draft and final versions). This folder also includes a vendor application and agreement from a local farmer from Toone, TN.
Included is a South Memphis Resident Health Survey Instrument filled out as a sample
"Addressing Urban Food Insecurity: Farmers Markets - Step-by-Step" and "Revitalizing South Memphis: Moving From Plans to Action". Presentation notes on the back of first presentation.

Includes South Memphis Revitalization Action Project (SoMe RAP), Farmers Market Preliminary Work Plan, press, "Planning and Design in The Bluff City: An Urban Issues Tour", Vance Avenue Choice Neighborhood Initiative.

did.unittitle: Mississippi River Trail Proposal, Scope of Services, Participatory Materials

scopecontent.p: Includes materials from the start of the University of Memphis' City and Regional Planning Department's first role with Professor Reardon as the principal investigator, inclusive of the proposal summary, the preliminary scope of services (for Mississippi River Corridor Trail Tennessee), the budget, the stakeholder contact list, meetings, Community Forum PowerPoint and some educational materials such as a pamphlet with maps of the trail. The Mississippi River Trail Plan connected to the Shelby County Bike Plan and other related Mississippi River projects through the national scenic by-ways initiative, urban trail planning in the Greater Memphis Region, and other plans connected to the river in neighboring states.
